pageContext.description: The woodcut showing 'Luther as Junker Jörg' is the last graphic portrait of Luther by Cranach and marked his return to the public stage in 1522. It was widely disseminated and continued to be printed until late into the 16th century. The inscription celebrates Luther's return employing the island of Patmos (where St John wrote the Apocalypse) as a metaphor for his time at the Wartburg.
pageContext.dimensions:
Sheet: 35.1 x 21.2 cm
Block: 28.5 x 20.8 cm
[Albertina, Wien, revised 2018]
pageContext.inscription:
IMAGO MARTINI LVTHERI EO HABIT V EX=/ PRESSA, QVO REVERSVS EST E[X] PATHMO VVITTE=/BERGAM ANNO DOMINI 1522.

Below:
Two couplets in single column:
Queasitus toties, toties tibi Roma petitus,/ En ego per Christum uiuo Lutherus adhuc.
Vna mihi spes est, quo non fraudabor, Iesus,/ Hunc mihi dum teneam, perfida Roma uale.

In three columns:
ANNVS CONFESSIONIS VVOR=/MACIAE 1521./ CaesarIs ante peDes, proCeres stetit ante potentes/ ACCoLa qVà Rheni VangIo LhtVs aDIt.
ANNVS PATHMI/ 1521./ A Rheno properans CapItVr, benè ConsCIa PathMI/ TeCta, Papae fVgiens retIna strVCta, petIt. 
ANNVS REDITVS EX/ PATHMO 1522./ CarLstaDII ob fVrias aD SaXonateCtarrCVrrIt,/ FaVCibVs ex saeVis rVrsVs oVesqVe rapIt.
